Materials - The Modular Tools Edition. A Guide to Material Properties
By Ayumu Nagasawa

This book contains statistics and information on all materials known to be compatible with Dr. Diyo's modular tools. It is essentially an updated version of the now dated Materials and You, Vol 2 written by Skyla.

page.title: Material Traits
page.text:
Some materials have traits that augment their natural uses.
- Reinforced: 10% chance per level of not using durability - Stonebound: The tool mines faster as it wears out, but does less damage - Jagged: The tool does more damage as it wears out, but mines slower - Writable: One extra modifier per piece - Tasty: Sometimes drops food items

page.title: Material Statistics:
page.text:
Materials have more possible attributes than when Skyla wrote his seminal work.
- Harvest Difficulty: What tool level is needed to mine it. - Harvest level: The maximum hardness a tool can mine. - Durability: How many times the material can be used before breaking. - Handle Mod: Tools with this as a handle multiply their durability by this amount. - Mining Speed: How quickly the tool mines materials it is effective against. - Attack Damage: How much extra damage this tool does when attacking - XP Required: How much XP this material requires to level up.

page.title: Wood
page.text: The lowliest of tool materials. Decent as a handle and levels pretty fast, but otherwise completely sub-par.

page.title: Stone
page.text: A basic, terrestrial, low-tech tool material. Levels and mines slowly, can harvest few types of materials, and is bad as a handle.

page.title: Flint
page.text: More durable than stone, but worse as a handle. Can harvest more materials than stone.

page.title: Paper
page.text: A very weak material. It's only redeeming feature is its ability to grant items extra modifier slots.

page.title: Slime
page.text: Soft and Springy. It seems to last a long time.

page.title: Bone
page.text: Less durable than stone, but mines and levels much faster. Also great as a handle.

page.title: Copper
page.text: A common terrestrial metal; extremely rare on this planet. Inferior to iron in every way, and levels quite slowly to boot.

page.title: Bronze
page.text: An alloyed metal slightly superior to iron. A good stepping stone to obtaining gold.

page.title: Iron
page.text: The base by which all other metals are compared. Good all-around terrestrial metal.

page.title: Nickel
page.text: Informally known as "Ferrous". A brittle but hard tech metal. High mining level and mining speed, but prone to breakage.

page.title: Invar
page.text: A tech alloy that does not change size when heated. Better than iron, but worse than steel. High reinforced level, but hard to level up.

page.title: Lead
page.text: A soft, heavy tech metal. Abnormally low mining level and mining speed, abnormally high durability.

page.title: Steel
page.text: A higher tech version of iron, better in every way.

page.title: Silver
page.text: A weak terrestrial metal better suited for ornamentation than tools. Better than brass in every way.

page.title: Platinum
page.text: A weak terrestrial alloy better suited for ornamentation than tools. Like electrum, but mines faster and levels nearly twice as quickly. High harvest level.

page.title: Cardboard
page.text: Better than paper in every way, except you can't write on it. Which basically makes it worse in every way.

page.title: Glue
page.text: Bindings made of glue help tools hold together. Anything else made of glue is a really bad idea.

page.title: Ruby
page.text: A rare gem. Unusually high attack damage.

page.title: Peridot
page.text: A rare gem. Unusually high Mining Speed

page.title: Sapphire
page.text: A rare gem. Unusually high durability.

page.title: Amethyst
page.text: A gem like diamond but used to make modular tools. Tools made with Amethyst are as good as diamond historically was.

page.title: Bedrockium
page.text: An amazingly tough metal. That's all that's good about it.

page.title: Enderium
page.text: A soft, pulsating alloy made from ender pearls. Takes a fantastically sharp edge... but has a hard time keeping it.

page.title: Signalum
page.text: An artificial alloy made from copper. Known to conduct redstone quite well. Like copper, but twice as durable and levels twice as fast.

page.title: Lumium
page.text: A synthetic, glowing metal not normally used in tools. Levels extremely fast, but...

page.title: Prometheum
page.text: A rather soft alien metal. Mines slowly, but is more durable than iron and levels up more quickly.

page.title: Deep Iron
page.text: An alien variant of iron. Softer, weaker, and slower but it levels up much more quickly.

page.title: Black Steel
page.text: An alien variant of steel. Weaker, slower, but far easier to level up than terrestrial steel.

page.title: Oureclase
page.text: A mediocre alien metal. Can mine everything that bronze can, but is worse in every way except levelling speed.

page.title: Thaumium
page.text: An artificially created alien metal. Can mine everything that iron can, but is slower and less durable. Its best feature is that it allows for an extra modifier slot.

page.title: Void Metal
page.text: A strange metal that repairs itself. Possibly biological in nature? Scientists seem uncomfortable working with it.

page.title: Mithril
page.text: A good alien metal, roughly comparable to alumite. It's less reinforced, but mines more and levels up much faster.

page.title: Haderoth
page.text: Alien alloy of Mithril and Rubracium, and better in every way. Much more durable than alumite, but lacks the reinforced trait.

page.title: Orichalcum
page.text: A great alien metal better than any known terrestrial metal. Like Manyullyn, but slightly less durable and levels very slowly.

page.title: Adamantine
page.text: An amazing alien metal better than any metal known to homeworld. Faster, harder, more reinforced, and faster levelling than manyullyn.

page.title: Atlarus
page.text: An amazing alien metal better than any metal known to homeworld. Better than Adamantine in almost every way; it lacks the reinforced trait.

page.title: Tartarite
page.text: A combination of alien metals and homeworld's metallurgic knowledge. Widely considered to be the ultimate metal.

page.title: Carmot
page.text: A highly enchantable alien metal. When making modular tools with it, they level very fast.

page.title: Celenegil
page.text: A amazingly enchantable alien alloy. The most enchantable thing known to man. Levels up five times as quickly as iron!

page.title: Astral Silver
page.text: An alien variant of Silver. Mines faster, levels much faster, and can mine more things, but is only marginally more durable.

page.title: Quicksilver
page.text: An alloy of Mithril and Silver. Armor made from this metal makes you move faster.

page.title: Kalendrite
page.text: A rare alien nether metal. Comparable to alumite, but twice as durable, slower, and levels more quickly.

page.title: Midasium
page.text: A strange alien nether metal. Mixing its dust with any other metal dust turns it to gold.

page.title: Ceruclase
page.text: An alien nether metal. Very similar in properties to steel, but it can mine slightly more things.

page.title: Vyroxeres
page.text: A strange alien nether metal that emits constant radiation.

page.title: Inolashite
page.text: An alloy of two alien nether metals. The alloying process makes it better in every way, except for its use as a handle.

page.title: Vulcanite
page.text: An unusual alien nether metal. Can mine everything Manyullyn can, just very slowly. It is much more durable, however.

page.title: Sanguinite
page.text: An amazing alien nether metal. Incredibly durable, but mines blocks slowly. It can mine most anything.

page.title: Ignatius
page.text: A strange nether stone. Its dust can be used as fuel.

page.title: Shadow Iron
page.text: An alien variant of iron. It's four times as durable, but slower and is very hard to level up.

page.title: Shadow Steel
page.text: An alien variant of steel. Incredibly durable. Hard to level up, but much easier than shadow iron.

page.title: Amordrine
page.text: An alloy of platinum with an alien nether metal. Better in every way than platinum, including mining and levelling speed.

page.title: Eximite
page.text: A rare alien metal found in pockets of endstone. Mines more than Alumite can, and is better than alumite in nearly every way, including being twice as durable.

page.title: Desichalkos
page.text: An alloy of two rare alien metals found in pockets of endstone. Better than anything developed on homeworld. More durable than adamantine, and levels faster, too.

page.title: Netherrack
page.text: Less durable than stone, but levels faster, harvests slightly more, and mines twice as fast.

page.title: Certus Quartz
page.text: Better than stone in every way.

page.title: Nether Quartz
page.text: Better than certus quartz in every way. Faster than most metals. Levels quickly. Still not great as a handle.

page.title: Obsidian
page.text: Brittle, but fast and has a high level of "Reinforced." Can harvest many blocks. Good for bindings.

page.title: Ghostwood
page.text: Can't hold an edge, but mines fast and lasts well as a handle. Levels up faster than slime-based materials.

page.title: Darkwood
page.text: A very hard wood. Comparable to copper, but slightly worse in every way except handle utility and levelling speed.

page.title: Fusewood
page.text: A very hard wood. Statistics identical to iron, but with a faster levelling speed and better use as a handle.

page.title: Bloodwood
page.text: A amazingly hard wood. Only slightly less durable than steel. Also better as a handle, but levels more slowly.

page.title: Cactus
page.text: Nicknamed the "Desert Wood". Mines much faster and is over twice as durable wood. Levels slowly, but not as slow as stone.

page.title: Plastic
page.text: A highly durable material with a low mining level. Almost incapable of levelling.

page.title: BlueSlime
page.text: Softer and Springier. It seems to last forever! Makes an exellent handle.

page.title: Pink Slime
page.text: The ultimate slime; the most durable material in existence. Makes fantastic handles, but like other slimes, it mines slowly.

page.title: Damascus Steel
page.text: A rediscovered ancient form of steel that naturally forms carbon nano-tubes. Extremely sharp, but more brittle and slower than normal steel.

page.title: Alumite
page.text: Alloy of iron, obsidian, and aluminum. Comparable to steel, but easier to make and levels up more slowly.

page.title: Cobalt
page.text: A common nether metal known to homeworld. It levels quickly and is faster than any other terrestrial metal.

page.title: Ardite
page.text: A common nether metal known to homeworld. It makes an excellent handle.

page.title: Manyullyn
page.text: The best metal known to homeworld; an alloy of two powerful nether metals. The gold standard against which any competing metal must exceed.

page.title: Brass
page.text: A weak terrestrial alloy better suited for ornamentation than tools. Has a high mining speed and levels quickly, however.

page.title: Angmallen
page.text: A mediocre terrestrial alloy of iron and gold. Less durable than iron, but levels much faster.

page.title: Hepatizon
page.text: A recently rediscovered ancient precious alloy. Nine times as durable as silver, and levels faster to boot.

page.title: Electrum
page.text: A weak terrestrial alloy better suited for ornamentation than tools. Better than silver in every way.

page.title: Pokefennium
page.text: A recently invented biometallurgic alloy. Can mine many rare alien minerals, but is comparitively weak and very hard to level up.

page.title: Fairy
page.text: A recently invented biometallurgic alloy. Comparable to Manyullyn, but about 1/4th the durability, levels more than twice as fast, and mines more quickly.

page.title: PigIron
page.text: A horrifying biometallurgic alloy invented while Dr. Diyo was intoxicated. When striking opponents, has a chance of dropping bacon. You monster.

page.title: Manasteel
page.text: A strange, easily worked metal that seems to repair itself only under certain unknown conditions.

page.title: Terrasteel
page.text: A supremely durable yet easily worked metal. All reports of successfully damaging it turn out to be mysteriously false.

page.title: Elementium
page.text: A strange metal that never responds to tests the same way twice. It seems soft when worked but durable once used as a tool.
